It still has enough unique elements to have a reason to exist. I'd say check out the first episode, as you should be able to figure out the general gist of the show by the end of it. For all I know, you may enjoy it a lot more than I did, hopefully at that.

I have to go very much out of my usual formula to review Kekkai Sensen, because it is a rather complicated caseâ¦ This is also going to be a very quick review, seeing as the shows âflawsâ are huge, and can be summarised quickly.

For starters, the show looks AMAZING, and is in my opinion the best looker of spring 2015. What truly sells the visuals is the directing. It gives of a sense of uncontrollable energy and fun, which upped the overall score for visuals quite the bit. The soundtrack is also pretty sweet. I actually found myself listening through the opening, instead of skipping through it, just because how amazing the song is. Same goes for the ending. Simply put, very listenable. As for the rest of the soundtrack, your usual mediocre background tracks sprinkled with some great standout tracks in-between for good measure ^_^

Talking about the story is the hardest part. After watching each episode, I had myself thinking; âMan, that was a great episode!â. The comedy is on point, the plot was amusing, the characters were entertaining, the shows structure was original (see recap episode 10.5), etc.. Overall a great show! And this worked out very well for the first 7 or so episodes, but after that point, one thing in particular became very apparent. Every episode feels like a separate work on its own, with only the main cast and the location to tie them together. There is no semblance of a story at all. One episode ends with the main cast looking over an army of demons, the next has our main character bribing a mushroom with hamburgers. What little there is of a story is basicly, New York is surrounded by a fog that has connected the demon world to the "human world". How? We're never told... In this new New York, monsters and humans have to co-exist. In the midsts of all this, our main protagonist has decided to move to New York, where after a series of coincidences, begins working for Libra, an organisation centered around keeping threats at bay. Aaand thats about it... There is hinted towards a story from time to another; the world is threatened by vampires, Leonard has self-doubt issues, Libra is a group of misfits trying to make a living, etc. but it is all so very subtile, until it is slapped straight in our face like a plot twist. The thing is, it is not a plot twist, just a speedy plot point. My major gripe here, is that it feels like the story is being sidetracked for comedy, or rather filler episodes, which have no place in a 12ep show. It could have been along the lines of character centric episodes, but the aforementioned "filler episodes" are merely arbitrary comedy skeets...

You could make the argument that Kekkai Sensen is a âslice of nothing ever happensâ comedy, and should be judged accordingly, but the show occasionally, tries hard to get its story across the board, and thus has to be judged as so. If Kekkai Sensen had been something along the lines of Kara no Kyoukai or Haruhi Suzumiya, where the episodes were not released chronologically, then the aforementioned ridiculously bad pacing and poorly tied together story could have been due to me just not understanding the plot due to unconventional conveying, but I canât even put the blame on such  a scenario.

As for the characters, there are just too many of them. But they all have two things in common. They are all based on character tropes, and they are all ridiculously two dimensional. I could go in depth (or as far as possible with the rather limited personality each and everyone were given) about each and every character, but instead il just list a few of the main. You hardly need anything more than this before you know everything about the characters. You have your run of the mill easygoing main character (Leonard Watch), the asshole (Zapp), the tough but straight guy (Klaus), deluded villain (Femt), obligatory love interest (Mary/White) and the whimp (William/Black). To the shows credit, episode 11 is pure characterisation, telling about the past of some of the main characters, but it is very much a "too little, too late" scenario. Instead, they should have put this episode closer to the mid-point. Indeed, it could take some of the suspense away from the anime, but at least the story would have been a tiny bit less non-sensical.

To summarise, Kekkai Sensen is a show that had a lot of potential. Every episode in and of itself were great, but the episodes themselves had no semblance of connection. The show falls flat on its face due to horrible pacing, limited character characterisation, little to none character development and a too short of a runtime. Say, if Kekkai Sensen had received a 26 episode runtime, the MABY the characters and the story would have had the time to be fully fletched out, instead of being the rushed mess that it is. The shows main selling points are definitively the animation, music and comedy, and with the exception of the aforementioned being great, there is very little to talk about... Kekkai Sensen could have been great, but ultimately is a rushed mess, and the final episode being posponed indefinitely further underlines that statement

I want to preface by saying that in this review, I will largely distinguish between the Aincrad arc and the Fairy Dance arc, seeing as how they are two separate stories and
vastly different in narrative style. The review has to include spoilers, but that shouldnât be a problem as everyone and their grandmother has seen SAO by now. Besides, a story should leave impact on the viewer if well executed, regardless of having been âspoiledâ or not.
Seeing as Sword Art Online has sparked quite the bit of controversy between its fanbase and the non-fans, please do keep in mind that this is my opinion only, and if yours differ, donât let mine affect you. As for my âtl;drâ thoughts on the show, itâs okayâ¦ It has several very apparent issues, namely in the narrative, but is still fairly entertaining.

The story of Sword Art Online is separated into two main arcs which can be described separately without delving too far into spoilers for either. The first of the arcs take place in a near future, wherein after years of research into virtual reality, a game by the name of Sword Art Online has been set to launch. What separates SAO from other VR games, is that instead of trying to immerse the viewer through visual, physical and auditory stimuli, it instead takes the playerâs consciousness into the game itself.
The launch of the game is set to have 10k players that managed to get the limited nerve-gear, the VR gear or what have you, where in-game the players soon notice a complete inability to log out. In a very thrilling scene, the gameâs creator, Kayaba Akihiko, reveals that they are now trapped in a game of life and death, in which the players have to clear the 100 floors of the game, with an ever so slight twist. If you die in the game, you die for real. Itâs soon after revealed that if the nerve-gear is forcefully removed, a mechanical micro-wave trap is set to pretty much fry their brain. Our hero Kirito goes on to join the âclearing squadâ, a group of elite warriors set on completing the 100 floors and returning to the real world, where he meets amongst others Asuna, one of the other main characters. The story implements amongst others, themes of jealousy as normal players fear and detest beta-testers, as they feel they have an unfair advantage and are egotistical people whom only care for themselves. Itâs a brilliant setup as a sclock action that is equally intriguing as it is fascinating from a sci-fi perspective.

The second arc, Fairy Dance takes place just two months after the Aincrad incident, where the vast majority of the survivors are either hospitalised or doing rehab after being mentally tormented in Aincrad. Sadly, not all the players have escaped the terror yet, as about 300 players are still in a state of comatose, Asuna being one amongst them. The game engine for Sword Art Online and the nerve-gear development kit has been bought by a company under the name of RECT Inc. which is headed by Asunaâs father. During one of Kiritoâs many times visiting Asuna at the hospital,
Kirito meets Asunaâs father and the head of the research institution at RECT, Sugou Nobuyuki. Turns out Asunaâs father has plans of marrying Sugou to her in one week, so that Sugou will inherit the company. This places Kirito on a one week timer to find a way to wake Asuna up from the comatose so that she can deny the marriage. The following day, Kirito is sent a screenshot from the new virtual reality mmorpg, ALfheim Online, where a figure that distinctly resembles Asuna can be seen, which drives Kirito to enter this new game in an attempt to save Asuna before the marriage is to take place, teaming up with amongst others his sister.

The narrative of Sword Art Online has a very heavy focus on adventure, which is one of the stronger element to the story. The worlds of Aincrad and ALfheim are massive and filled to the brim with content. The worlds are nothing short of beautiful, and I actually felt an incentive to explore these worlds. I would actually have wanted to take part of this adventure, had it not been for the whole perma-death thing. 
In the video game industry, there exists this little term known as âludo-narrative dissonanceâ, which in short terms means that the gameplay and the story is in direct conflict with each other. A more recent example would be Fallout 4 where the story is about rushing to find your son, whilesât the gameplay entices exploring the world and following the main story whenever you feel like. Similarly with the story of SAO, you would expect the clearing squad to be carefully planning their advances ahead because actual lives are at stake, but we see them often running head first in to something that can otherwise be described as a massacre. Likewise, you would expect everyone to use their off time, grinding lower level monsters for experience, but half of the first arc is about establishing a more mellow tone with minigames and side-activities that ultimately donât yeald any substantional reward.

The characters are what most commonly receives criticism, from fans and non-fans alike, and the vast majority of those problems derive from how the story attempts to portray the protagonist Kirito. Describing Kirito without talking about his actions is pretty hard, seeing as he is nothing short of bland and boring, with a side dish of inconsistency. The few times the show tries to give him any kind of depth, it shoots itself of by having him be the edgiest, moodiest teen ever since Wit. studio became a thing. The show almost acnowledges itâs lack of ability to progress Kiritoâs character, so it introduces a character in the form of Kirito and Asunaâs artificial inteligence daughter Yui to do the developing for them. The most noteworthy example of inconsistency would be the incident wherein Kirito announces himself as a Beater, essentially announcing himself and all other beta-testers as villains, and painting a massive target over his face. The Kirito we âknowâ would try to reason with the others in his shy demeanour, but the Kirito in this scene acts pompous and witty, and although it is supposed to be Kirito putting on an act, the act only understates that all beta-testers must be feared, and forces Kirito into hiding his power-level from other players for a while, because heâs the dumbass that threw the rock that created the rockslide.

The fact that Kirito is portrayed as so ridiculously overpowered, is probably what is the spawn of the vast majority of plot-holes in Aincrad. Kirito at a fairly early point in the game join a small team of far lower levelled players, whom he trains with for a while. Whilest theyâre training, Kirito has to hide his level due to the whole beater incident, but we as viewers can see that his level is about double theirs. Whilesât paying with them, Kirito levels about twice as fast, which would be impossible, seeing as a normal mmorpg would have some kind of exp-share system, and even though such a system were to not be present, the exp-target on higher levels should be far greater than the exp-target on lower levels. And because he hid his level, his teammates get overly-confident, and waltz straight into a trap which kills everyone but Kirito, because of his inability to communicate with his friends, which determins Kirito to party on his own from now on, which should in any mmorpg stunt his exp gain. To add further insult to injury, the incident is never resolved, having Kirito be trapped, before doing yet another time-skip in which Kirito no longer is inside the dungeon. How did he get out? Throught he powers of deus-ex machina? Kirito actually has several deus-ex machina incidents throughout Aincrad, another being how already in the first episode, it is stated that players have no perception of pain in this game, yet we are on several occasions treated to torture scenes which lack any and all impact because we KNOW that nobody is getting hurt. There is no pain sensory. A third one would be how during a boss raid in which the people Kirito is playing with are getting demolished by the boss, so he decides to use a dual wielding skill to destroy the
boss. Why didnât he do so earlier? Delaying showing of the skill cost the lives of many people. After the fight has been resolved, he gets questioned about how he got the skill, and simply replies with âit was just there one dayâ. You mean to tell me the single most over-powered skill in the game is
unique to Kirito, and he go it out of nowhere without doing anything? That is as close to the definition of plot convenience as one can get. Another noteworthy scene, although not related to plot-holes, is when Kirito gets jumped by 7 guys whom manage to output less dps than Kiritoâs hp-regeneration, obliterating any sense of tension there was. 

An attribute to Kirito being overpowered, is how ignorant or stupid the rest of the player base seems to be. It is establised fairly early that in SAO there are about 10.000 players, and that about 1000 players were beta-testers. Yet no-one except Asuna come even remotely close to the power of
Kirito. Sword Art Online was supposedly the most hyped game of itâs are, and the 10.000 copies of the nerve-gear were sold out within hours. Yet Kirito has to exposit the mechanics of a rather basic mmorpg to whomever the fuck he comes across. The vast majority of players seem to have never
touched a game before. And although the beta-testers take up 1/10th of the player base, yet Kirito NEVER stumble across any players that could be considered at a skill where they could have been beta-testers. The only one that comes anywhere close to Kirito in skill, is Asuna, and she states
during her first encounter with Kirito that she knows fuck all about mmorpgâs, let alone SAO.

At last thereâs Asuna. Although Asuna is somewhat straight forward tsundere, with little to nothing to differentiate her from the overly-saturated tsundere-waifuâs there are. What Asuna lacks in originality, she makes up with incredible fluidity, vibrance and believability. Reminder that the difference between inconsistency and vibrance being one is a characters personality limiting itâs options and then choosing the one that does not correspond with personality, whilesât the other is a characters personality enabling more options. The aforementioned traits are what makes for some absolutely fantastic character interactions, seeing how despite Kirito having no personality at all, Asuna is still able to create chemistry between the two. The relationship between Kirito and Asuna is ironically better than the relationships displayed in the vast majority of romance anime, and it is solely due to the character of Asuna, and it in the scenes with Asuna that Kirito displays what is called faint signs of human emotion and the ability to interact with other human beings. It is also a rare feat to see characters entering a functioning relationship in an anime without it ending with someone getting blue-balled. Now, sadly I have to say that Asuna is still largely an attribute to Kirito as the vast majority of her actions are either affected or as a result of Kiritoâs actions. Asuna is still THE redeeming feature to Aincrad, and itâs a fucking shame she plays little to no role in Fairy Dance except to be mutilated and serve as a reward for Kirito. What was the animeâs saviour and the one player that was on par with Kirito in strength, is reduced to nothing but a damsel in distress, and makes what could have been the better of the two arcs far less enjoyable than the former.

Fairy Dance only introduces one major character, in the form of Kiritoâs sister, Kirigaya Suguha, or Leafa as she is know in the game. Sadly, she is extremely arbitrary, as in if you completely remove her from the story, nothing would change, with the small exception that there would be a lot less exposition as she serves the role as narrator for the majority of the story, or dare I say, info-dumper. For the vast majority of the journey through ALfheim, sheâs nothing more but a bystander, with the exception of one incident where she acts as support from Kirito as he goes on to fight 12 people of a rivalling race, before turning into a demon and demolishing the 12. Iâd love to say I knew why or how he turned into a demon, but Kirito himself states that he does not know how it happened, and the power never becomes relevant ever again. If Kirito had just used âthe power of plot convenienceâ earlier, he could have easily defeated them without Suguha, rendering her only useful appearance arbitrary. She only serve the purpose of falling in love with Kirito, to ultimately get heartbroken.

Lets go over the two villains of Sword Art Online, Kayaba Akihiko and Sugou Nobuyuki. Before talking about them on an individual level, I wish to go over a villains purpose in any clichÃ© protagonist vs. antagonist story, and what differentiates a good from a bad character in this scenario. In making a protagonist or antagonist, there are three major ways one can fuck it up.

1. Have the character lack a motive : For the character to be effective, the viewer must be able to root for him; to be immersed. Easiest way to do this, is by having a clichÃ© revenge plot, in which the character is out to punish those whom has done him unjust.

2. Have the character have a too strong motive : Although the viewer must be able to root for the character, there must also be an incentive for the villain to be the one to loose in the end. The easiest way to pull this off, is to have him be âevilâ or âgoodâ. If weâre talking about a protagonist vs. antagonist; having the protagonistâs motive be more justificable than that of the antagonist. But on the other hand, if the characterâs motives are made ridiculous to the point that the viewer looses the ability to resonate with him, he looses all sense of believability, and becomes either laughable or edgy.

3. Have the characterâs motives conflict with one and another or be overly-complex : A good protagonist or antagonist is one whom has a motive, either for personal gain, or for the gain of a society, group or individual whom he cares for. Although the character can stray from his path during the journey, the ultimate goal should be one that is fairly precise and easy to understand. If you make the villains goal overly-complex or the derivative of a series of motives, the story becomes unfocused and much less immersive. Either that or pretentious.

Kayaba Akihiko for the most part plays the rolle of âmysterious villainâ. We know nothing of his motives, who he is or his backstory. Remember how I said Aincrad had a heavy focus on adventure? Well, as the conclusion of SAO nears, our heroes are still only at the 25th floor, rendering 25% of the adventure unexplored. In one of the biggest buzzkills ever, Kayaba challenges Kirito to a one on one duel which ends in Kiritoâs favour, ultimately stealing away 25% of the adventure away from the viewer. Essentially promised content is being taken away from us as viewers. The arc also ends on a massive anti-chlimax, in which Kirito gets the opportunity to talk to Kayaba and ask him about his motivation for killing all these players, and Kayaba reveals how âhe has long forgotten the reasonâ. Last time I checked, people rarely forget why they commit genocide against a culture (gaming culture this time around). The only thing we know about Kayaba in the end, is that he is a scientist that developed a game to kill people. He is the âevilâ obstacle that the protagonist has to clear.

Sugou Nobuyuki is a clusterfuck on a whole other level. Back to how I in the definition of a villain said that if you overdo the villain, he ends up as either pathetic or edgy. Sugou is just that; Kiritoâs motivation to rescue Asuna is of course because he loves her, whilesât Sugouâs motivation to keep her in ALfheim is for economical gain. If he manages to convince her to marry him, he inherits the company which he is 2nd in charge of currently. Okay, perfect. We have a villain with his motivations and a protagonist with his motivations. The villain is out for personal economical gain, whilesât the protagonist is out for love. But instead of having the point come to an end from here, this ridiculous plot about brain-washing the players and taking over the world is introduced, and Sugou is also made to be a sadist with a fetish for sadomasochism. There was no need to have S&M in a childrenâs anime about a teenager saving his girlfriend in a video-game. It just makes for a painful and degrading watching experience, as the S&M scenes are drawn to look almost erotic. The whole arc about world dominance is also more confusing that intriguing. He obliterates the perfect balance of good vs. evil, and becomes the overly-despicable, impossible to resonate with, confusing villain.

The âguidelines for a main characterâ obviously apply to Kirito as well. During the entirety of Sword Art Online, Kirito is pretty much walking around without purpose nor reasoning. He is not part of a team, he is not part of the clearing squad, he has no goals in mind whatshowever. There is no incentive to care about Kirito. Iâd much rather watch any other member of the clearing squad. Most people that have watched SAO, will say that during the ALfheim arc, Kirito feels like a better protagonist whom is much more emotionally present. This is largely due to how during ALfheim, Kirito actually has a goal in mind. A driving force if you will. And although the motive in fairy dance is rather clichÃ©, at leas there is a motive. The motive makes it easier to relate or resonate with Kirito, but he still lacks human emotions, he is still in-able to communicate with other human beings and he is still as inconsistent as in Aincradâ¦

Iâm somewhat torn about the visuals in Sword Art Online. On one hand, Sword Art Online features some of the best artwork Iâve ever seen, he character models look fantastic, the particle effects look for the most part great and the overall consistency of the visuals is fairly high (shots fired at Manglobe). And although some of the disproportionate figures, especially faces, have become memes on the internet over the years because of how ridiculous people think they are, they added a lot of impact and power to the frames. On the other hand, the cinematography had a tendency to crumble during fighting scenes, especially those featuring more than two characters slugging it out. Whenever more than two characters were present on-screen, most of them would be still-framed, and in stead of animation, there would be shaky-cam effects and poorly displaced particle effects, notoriously the horizontal lines that would go from one end to the other of the screen, making the screen even more confusing. As for the one on oneâs, although from an animation and art standpoint, the choreography and the particle effects are still all over the place. Also noteworthy regarding shot composition; As an attribute to the anime trying to portray Kirito as a badass, the fight scenes had a tendency to focus on him, regardless of the enemyâs size. Be it an enemy at the same size of Kirito, this would work out perfectly, but if the enemy is something along the lines of a 15foot monster, half of the opponent would be put off-screen, making the already clustered cinematography even more confusing. One could consider the scenes as experimental, but if thatâs so, then A1âs freelancers bit an apple too big to chew.

Oh, the soundtrackâ¦ Where do I begin? The soundtrack is entirely done by Yuki Kajiura, so thereâs already reason to have high expectations, and I can confirm that the soundtrack is the second best thing in Sword Art Online, after Asuna of course. Although the soundtrack is somewhat textbook fantasy adventure, the execution and the finesse that Yuki Kajiura adds is what it makes it stand out from the rest, and it actually had me mesmerising back to when I was younger when I watched the first Narnia movie for the first time! Sadly there are very few standout tracks from the bunchâ¦ On the other hand, if the soundtrack doesnât interest you, then at least the openings are sure to do so!

With the general basis for the anime laid forth, Iâm going to start tearing the story of Sword Art Online apart. Take note on how I will still be separating the Aincrad arc and the Fairy Dance arc, as they serve different purpose and approach to narrative. Before tearing the story apart, know that thereâs a total cognitive dissonance between the two stories, in which during the Aincrad arc, the clearing team is rushing through dungeons with all their forces, loosing hundreds of men in the process, when they could have taken their time on the lower levels, farming low level monsters until they would be able to overpower the higher levels. On the other hand, during the Fairy Dance arc, Kirito is being placed on a one week timer, whilesât for the most part, it feels like heâs dicing around doing fuck all. This is extremely contradicting to the message the two arcs try to give the viewer. Whilesât Fairy Dance is a rather straight forward adventure about hero saving damsel in distress, Aincrad actually had a message. People were actually enjoying themselves in Sword Art Online, even though they were in many ways trapped. Some even preferred this world over the real one. There is never any sense of urgency in Fairy Dance, where there should be, whilesât in Alfheim, there is an urgency without reasoning. Now, Iâve had people say that people having trust in virtual-reality mmorpgâs after the SAO incident is ridiculous, but as a comparison, people still fly in planes after 9/11, so I donât find it to be that impossible. I do on the other hand find it strange that they would use the exact same game engine as SAO, and it might have taken a few years before people would fully trust it again, but I digress.

Firstly, letâs tear apart the actual game that is Sword Art Online. Over the years Iâve played my fair share of mmorpg, and the only one I can think of that closely resembles the game mechanics of SAO, is RuneScape, which comparing SAO to RuneScape is the only way Iâm able to have the gameâs design approach make sense. But the mechanics as an mmorpg make no sense at all. In any traditional mmorpg, partying with other players is far more effective exp wise, than going alone, which is  where Iâm referring to RuneScape which is largely a single player experience. SAO, with a complete lack of any quests, tasks or challenges is a grinding mmorpg, and although there are some quests, etc. RuneScape is largely a grinding game as well. Yet, to defeat anything with a higher level than you, it is advised to team up with friedly players, yet Kirito manages to essentially single handedly crush any boss, wether equal or far above his level. Once again Kirito being overpowered crashes with the story.

The narrative in the Aincrad arc is a cluster-fuck to say the least, spending time on filler, before taking massive time-skips, skipping over content vital to the context of several key events. Referring to the incident in which Kirito announced himself as a âBeaterâ, without having resolved being branded a villain, Kirito is becomes a vital member of the the clearing squad in-between two episodes, having me as a viewer ask myself questions like âwhen did he join?â, âhow was he granted admission?â, âwhy isnât he receiving any backlash?â, and so forth. A lot of the bonding between Kirito and Asuna is also being skipped, jumping from being mere party members one episode, to sharing beds in the next one, implying that the writers donât know how do character bonding and development, thus outright skipping it. This being a particularly massive shame, seeing as the relationship between Kirito and Asuna is easily the strongest part of the anime due to how strong Asuna is as a character. Also, a great deal of the narrative outright does not make any sense. Call them plot holes if you will. Take the basis of SAO as a whole, the nerve gear. From what we know, the nerve-gear has a built in radio-wave-mechanic that basically fries your brain if you either 1. die in-game or 2. have your helmet be forcefully removed. Later in the anime, weâre introduced to the mechanic of reviving other players within a time-period of 30-seconds (a mechanic never taken into effect). Does that mean that the nerve-gear waits 30-seconds before frying your brain on death? To me, it seems as the nerve-gear and virtual-reality mmorpg are afterthoughts on how to make the scenarios that take place in SAO possible, which could have been taken care of by having this be a by the book fantasy setting.

ALfheim Online, although a direct product of Sword Art Onlineâs game engine, features slightly different mechanics from those Sword Art Online had, namely there are several races which all feature distinct design approaches which differentiate them enough to serve as different classes, and all the skills and items from SAO has been rendered invalid in ALfheim. Those familiar with the Elder Scrolls series will be familiar with the race design approach. Similar to the mmorpg Elder Scrolls Online, the different races serve as different clans or kingdoms, with the ability to engage war on each and another.  Despite all the skills from SAO supposedly being invalid in ALfheim, Kirito is still able to dual-wield, and even refers to an attack as a skill at one point. Although ALfheimâs core mechanics make a great deal more sense than those of SAO, they as well start to crumble the further we get into the story. In particular during episode 21, thereâs a worldwide server maintenance, in which all the players are forcefully logged out. During the downtime, Asuna is still able to move around freely (for some inexplicable reason), and uses the opportunity to escape the birdcage in which sheâs been locked in. Sneaking around the tops of the three branches, it never occurs to her that she can jump of the branches and fly down to the main land, but instead she heads into the core of the three, where she finds a loophole opportunity to log out. Hesitating to press the log-out button, she gets mutilated in one of the most un-called for scenes in anime history. It served no purpose to the narrative, it was not comedic and it was not erotic (nor is SAO erotic by any means), yet itâs there, only to catch the viewer of guard. On top of that, the result of all of this bullshit, is that she getâs thrown back into the birdcage, rendering the entire unpleasantry pointless. On top of that, scenes like this has no place in an anime like this. A clichÃ© childrenâs fantasy story has noting to do with tentacle rape or sadomasocism. They manage to ruin the mmorpgâs believability by adding an arbitrary unpleasantry.

Sword Art Onlineâs is far from horrible, despite what the haters say. On the other hand, it is far from godâs gift to mankind as the fans have branded it. From a literary perspective, it manages to fuck things up in about every way possible. However, the strong soundtrack and fantastic artwork redeems the anime quite a bit, and Iâd say it is still one of the more watchable out there despite the flaws, and I personally think that everyone should watch it, wether it be for pure entertainment reasons, or as a means of training your analytical skills, because Sword Art Online truly is the pinnacle of horrible writing.

Sword Art Online will to me forever be the perfect example of how to adapt a work: âIf the source material is awful, change itâ. If the same amount of effort put into the visuals and the soundtrack was put into the script and characters, Sword Art Online could have become amongst the greatest within
the fantasy adventure genre.

__~~~The show that gave me a new term for a certain pet peeve. ~~~
__
I have been watching anime for a long time. Actively I would say 11 years. Throughout that time I do not remember a situation where I was so fixated on one certain aspect that completely capitulated everything else. That is where I am with the faces in Kakugurui. 
These issues with obnoxious faces is nothing new for me. I have the same feelings for Daily Lives of High School Boys and Drifters. But Kakegurui has achieved a level of obnoxious faces into a territory that has not been explored that I shall deem as egregious faces. 

The showâs art style is presented in a way that resembles sadistic hentai with these faces. I for one am not a masochist nor a sadist that will get enjoyment from an entertainment medium that way. I also am not a hentai fan so when you add the sweat and the lips/drool that helps take it to that egregious level. 

This shows theme is based on a school where gambling gets you to the top of the totem pole. I for one am someone who likes the game of poker. I watch the World Series of Poker every year. I even had a favorite poker player in Phil Hellmuth. So I was optimistic that at least like the action in Drifters I can find satisfaction in the gambling of the show. 

Unfortunately the gambling we got was a mix of redundant themes and girls over-powering on masochism. But even if the gambling was more satisfactory it is hard to enjoy any battle of strategy when your bombarded by egregious faces left and right. 

By this point I already had all these negative feelings towards Yumeko. Queue stage left a Yumeko on steroids named Midari Ikishima. During her dedicated episodes is where I just lost all hope for this show because when you put the theme of death into the show that changes everything. This isnât about riding the economic train to the top of a gambling school. Your bringing in the theme that you can actually die in this school. That was the moment the stake went into  the heart for the setting. 

Midari is also apart of the student council that are the main villains of the show. They are a conglomerate of individuals that have come together to hold a monopoly on the school. The basis of the show is for Yumeko to take them down one by one. The entirety of the show continues to try and make the student council even more sadistic than Yumeko herself. They try to establish a higher-level sadism that is not accepted to make you not like these characters. But if you already have Yumeko pass that level the effect is just completely negated. 

Basically every character was doing these gambling orgasms. It is the same issue the entire show. Even when they gave me an architype that I tend to enjoy in a villain in glasses. The enthusiasm dwindled away quite quickly thanks to once again from Yumekoâs orgasms. So I can confidently say that the Characters, Enjoyment, and Art are all a 1 out of 10. 

Iâve already covered how the setting is decapitated. But we do have progression. There is an end game to the show. They do not waste much time with frivolous OVA content. That is something I can put up as a 2 out of 10. Now bringing it up to a 3 out of 10 is another story. There was a lot of empty transition from going to the next student council member. There also was never a proper hierarchy build out so I can understand the level of difficulty increasing. They donât really have much time to build up to it though. Their goal seemed to be to have the main event match-up in this entry. I can settle of a borderline 3 out of 10 with the story. 

So what it comes down to is music. I tend not to deviate my music score much from the rest of the show. I tend not to value it that highly. The ending song is okay but I do have major issues with the performance from Tia in the OP. There was a real turn-off for me listening to this nasally running on voice she used in the song. Iâve skipped the OP every time since episode 2. So with that Iâd have to give another 1 out of 10. 

 Iâve never experienced something so off-putting in anime like Kakegurui and it is going to be a benchmark for me when it comes to off-putting themes. If anything is as off-putting as the egregious faces and gambling orgasms then it will be a contender for a 1 out of 10 on my rating scale. For Anilist I'll give the show a 10 out of 100. Because at least were not getting episodic themes. So the story will keep it at a base 1 out of 10.

Girlfriends, boyfriends, Iâm sure most of us have wanted one at some point, or already have one. For those of us who donât have one, do not fret, Hajimete no Gal is here to indulge you into the experience of having a girlfriend or boyfriend, whether you want it or not. This will not be a painless experience however, so strap yourself in and prepare for the worst, and I mean it.

Imagine this: You are just an ordinary guy, and your classmates forced you to ask a hot girl in your class to date you. After she almost turns you down like the loser you are, she instead decides to accept becoming your girlfriend, but is it too good to be true? In most cases, yes, this would be too good to be true, however, in Hajimete no Gal we say "screw the rules! "and make the unlikely happen.

While the premise may seem enticing at first, the show doesnât do much to expand on it, leaving you with an empty shell of nothingness for a majority of the show. If youâve seen at least a couple harem/ecchi anime before, then youâll probably see the pattern Hajimete follows through its episodes. This doesnât mean that it has nothing going for it, because it does. Every episode centers on our main character experiencing something new for the first time, whether that is visiting his girlfriendâs house, going to karaoke or even getting a job. Of course, you also have your obligatory beach episode that every harem/ecchi seems to have, but I wonât get into that too much, since I donât mind it.

Another problem is the pacing, it feels really rushed. One moment the characters are doing something random, and in the next scene something dramatic happens without leaving any time to digest what happened. This wouldn't be a problem if the show in question was all about the randomness like Nichijou, but when you add a random element to what seems to be a semi-serious show, at least for me it doesn't work at all.

If you thought you were going to get some nice uncensored scenes, then think again. I watched the uncensored version, but instead of being presented with uncensored material, they instead decided to censor a guyâs boner through his pants, because thatâs totally the best way to make someone interested in your show. The censored version is even worse by the way, they censor stuff like the girlâs panties for no reason, which is a big no-no for me especially when itâs an ecchi show.

The characters are for the most part dull and forgettable. The male characters except for the main character donât really serve a purpose except for being there, which of course entails in almost no character development whatsoever. Thereâs even a literal pedophile saying that he only wants to fuck little girls, and that 15 year olds are too old for him. Thereâs not much else to say about them other than that you can literally replace them with clones of Ichika from Infinite Stratos and the experience wouldnât change that much.
The females are for the most part attractive, if you ignore their humongous almost Eiken-level boobs and the fact that their personalities are barely there. If youâve even seen a screenshot from the show, or even the cover, you should know what Iâm talking about. They feel unnaturally large, especially for high schoolers, since you are not supposed to have such big boobs when youâre between 16 and 18 years old, but hey, what do I know, right? This is anime weâre talking about, where the impossible can happen at any time because the creator allows for it.

As for the art, it isnât that bad, but it doesnât stand out either. There was never a moment where I went âwow, this is totally worth it for the artâ instead it was kind of just meh. It serves a purpose, but donât expect anything fancy, since youâll be disappointed.

The opening was decent enough, and I actually liked the ending theme, it was catchy and felt like a nice end to each episode. Other than that, the rest of the OST was pretty forgettable, mostly just common background music for the sake of having music.

Hajimete no Gal had some okay moments, but the sheer amount of pointless scenes, straight up useless characters and unnecessary censorship pushes my buttons just a little bit too far, and in the end it was a massive disappointment. What could have been an interesting and creative take on the genre instead becomes your run of the mill harem/ecchi show with too many dumb things to explain. If you can, stay away from this show, it is really bad.

There comes a time when something becomes so bad that not even the good aspects can salvage it, and this is certainly the case with Pupa. From repetitive events to scenes that almost made me vomit, Pupa does everything it can to make you hate it. If that was your intention Pupa, you certainly did a great job in doing so.

If I had to describe Pupaâs âstoryâ (if you can even call it that) in two words, it would be âdreadful messâ. Itâs basically just torture porn. Utsutsu, our main male character, tries to save his sister Yume from becoming a monster due to some virus, who then proceeds to eat him alive. After sheâs done with him, he revives, because he also has some sort of virus, and the episode is over. Next episode, rinse and repeat until episode 11. Episode 12 however is completely different, but it establishes nothing remotely interesting and leads me to believe that the creators just gave up and said, âWell, if people didnât like episodes 1-11, then why not fuck with them and produce a useless ending that has nothing to do with the rest of the show?â âGreat idea man! *High five*â

The characters are as generic as you can get, the only thing I remember about them is that Utsutsu has a scar over his left eye. Thatâs it; they left no impact on me. Not even the black-haired woman (who I think Iâve seen in a hentai by the way) made me care about her, she was just kind of there.



I think the worst part about Pupa is the fact that they decided to censor out some of the bloody and violent parts, while keeping in others. For instance, in one scene a knife is censored out for some reason (donât know why), but then like a minute later Yume is in the middle of eating her brother and thatâs not censored? What is that about? You decide to censor out a knife but not a guy being EATEN ALIVE? Come on, you can do better than that.

Continuing from my last paragraph, even if the show wasnât censored and we got to see all the blood and gore, the art and animation is so basic that it wouldnât even look decent. Youâd think that since the episodes are only 4 minutes long, they would have to spend less money per episode which would lead to better art and animation, but thatâs where you would be wrong. They instead decide to save as much money as possible by making low quality frames and character models.

I canât really enjoy something that portrays itself so badly and makes me want to stop watching it. I canât see how anyone would enjoy this, unless youâre into torture porn or vore I guess. But even then, there are better options out there that donât make you want to rip your hair out at how infuriating it is. Not many shows have made me angry while watching them, but Pupa became one of them, and for that I salute you; Youâve entered the pit of no return, the place where only the worst of the worst get permission to enter. You can never leave, and you will never hear from me again. Say goodbye Pupa, you will not be missed.

To summarize, Pupa is an awful mess that not only repeats itself every episode and has a horrible ending that ties nothing together, but also makes you angry at the fact that the creators actually made this irredeemable pile of junk. Donât watch this, unless youâre a complete masochist or into torture porn and vore. You have been warned.

Why in the everliving FUCK do people like this show? I just don't fucking get it. I L.O.V.E. this genre. Anyone who knows me will immediately tell you that when it comes to anime I'm the biggest fucking sap ever. It doesn't take me much to get invested in a romantic story, and even less so to get me to feel heavy emotional pangs and sympathize with the characters. More than one anime romance drama has left me in tears, but this show has me crying for completely different reasons.

This show started off fine. A dumb weak sci-fi premise where the future versions of all the characters send back letters so their earlier selves can avoid their regrets. Seems like a weak idea for a show if the characters never fuck up or create any drama, but whatever, I can roll with it. I'm a sucker for romance after all. There's this new kid in town, Kakeru, who is the express subject of nearly all of these letters. Turns out that he's sad as fuck because of some bad life stuff, and ends up offing himself because all of the core cast are just bad friends and didn't really support, or some shit like that. 

Of course, our special needs MC, Naho, likes this guy, but is too cripplingly disabled to say it, like all portrayals of high school girls in anime. Normally, this wouldn't be an issue, and we'd spend 13 episodes of high school bullshit getting them sort-of together and end on a half-assed, half kiss like every other shoujo ever, but now we have to save Kakeru's life. It's alright though, we'll just use the magic future letters to make sure we don't fuck up... UNTIL WE IMMEDIATELY START IGNORING THEM ON EPISODE. FUCKING. ONE. Naho is more dense than a fucking neutron star and decides to throw the magic letters that are ALWAYS RIGHT out the fucking window because she "just can't handle it". 

I get why she doesn't from a story perspective; this show would have no drama at all if they just followed their future selves' instructions, but that isn't good for us as an audience. If we know what the two possible outcomes are, we just don't care, because a show like this reads from the first episode that everything is going to be OK despite a couple bumps in the road. Orange just can't fucking decide if it wants to be some sort of "we choose our own destiny" bullshit or just a normal high school shoujo romance, and it suffers heavily because of it. 

From an aesthetic perspective, this show leaves everything to be desired. The shoujo fat-lipped art style is incredibly generic and the animation is the farthest thing from fluid I've seen in a long time. This isn't even counting the numerous 'QUALITY' moments that line the series middle section. The consistency takes a hard drop off a cliff at episode 3 (which is also where the anime jumps the shark from the manga, BTW), and doesn't even remotely pick up again until episode 10. Literally half drawn frames are there for you to see plain as day. Music is also incredibly generic. Everything about this show is generic. And bad.

Burn this show in the dumpster fire it deserves to be left in. There are hundreds of mediocre anime romances and a handful of great ones that you could be watching instead. Avoid this like the plague.

[__For more from this season and others, check out my blog!__](http://thebeanwolf.blogspot.com/2016/09/summer-2016-anime-in-review.html)

We're never going to get a worthy Beserk adaptation. This is something that fans of the manga have just come to accept after God knows how many years of waiting. The 90's anime really wasn't all that bad, but it was a slideshow even for time period, and the Golden Age films were an unsettling mix of decent hand drawn art and horrid CG, not to mention they just retold the same story that we've seen adapted twice now. The Golden Age arc is effectively a prequel to the rest of the Berserk franchise, so have twenty years where nothing but that was adapted is incredibly frustrating, especially with a series that has as strong and beautiful a piece of source material as Berserk does.

Berserk (2016) takes the terrible CG from the Golden Age movies and makes it the main focus. There are smatterings of hand drawn art mixed in, but never enough to offset the CG and just enough to remind you what this new series could have been. We're finally pushing past the Golden Age arc into the core Berserk story, but the studio took a massive liberty with the source material and condensed about 400 panels into just five minutes of animation to accelerate the story to where Guts first encounters Farnes and her group of knights. This is the "Black Swordsman" arc, which serves to introduce us to the broken and desperate post-Eclipse Guts, and like I said above, is cut to about 5% of its original content. From this point, more large changes from the source come at a rapid pace. The entirety of the "Lost Children" arc, one of the most emotionally powerful arcs from the manga, is completely cut, with the story accelerating to Guts being captured at Farnes' camp. There is also an anime original (but Miura directed) episode that fills that gap between the camp and the beginning of the "Conviction" arc, that is decent and introduces us to just how damaged Farnes really is, but is still tragically low quality compared to the source.

It's at this little-less-than-halfway point that the adaptation really starts to step it up and make you mad at what you're given. The "Conviction" arc is more or less extremely well adapted, as in true to the source, in its entirety; it's just adapted into complete garbage. Aesthetically, Berserk (2016) is about as bottom of the barrel as it gets for the CG portions. CG movement is jerky and unnatural, models "pop" jarringly out of the average backgrounds, and the texturing is incredibly low-fidelity. They try to emulate Miura's hashing-based shading by slapping a half-assed version of the effect on top of the 3D models, and it does nothing but look incredibly stupid. The small amount of 2D, hand drawn art is actually decent but nowhere near the quality that Berserk deserves. The sound design is also particularly terrible, which is a shame because the VA and music are both actually pretty alright.

Everything about Berserk (2016) is just a massive letdown, and is even moreso considering the studio seems to really wants to adapt the source into animation faithfully (outside the strangely accelerated start) but obviously does not have the budget or talent to do so. I'm not sure what has to be done for Berserk to get the high quality anime adaptation that it deserves, but I'm convinced that it must be fucking impossible.

Go read the manga, don't waste your time with this.

I like to think that I've sat through some terrible anime in my time. Black Bullet, Comet Lucifer, Mayoiga, Another, you name it. I'm a 'NoDrop' watcher, so I've seen my fair share of shit shows. Never did I think that a show would come along that was so incredibly bad, so intellectually bankrupt, that it would completely redefine what I would consider a "bad anime series".

I'll spoil the score for you right now: Taboo Tattoo is a legitimate 0/10. It has zero merit as a piece of art, animated work, or general entertainment. I would have much rather gouged out my own eyes than watched this series, and given the choice I'd have reached for the nearest rusty spoon in an instant. This show has no idea where it's going, what it's doing, or what it wants to do. At first, I thought this show was going to this season's Bungou Stray Dogs, where the story is retarded but at least the character designs and fights were cool enough to keep me halfway interested, but the animation quality for Taboo Tattoo took a complete nosedive after episode 1, devolving into commonplace CG and slideshow-like animation from that point forward. I distinctly remember a scene where a walking character simply didn't have an animated walk cycle, and instead her drawing translated about the screen freely. The music and art are also incredibly generic and bad, especially for a studio like J.C. Staff who at the very least produces consistently endearing character designs.

With a show this bad, you'd think that it was trying to be some sort of parody, but it's not. The characters of the show are it's standout terrible feature, with all of them having contrived and ridiculously plot convenient super powers that manifest out of tattoos of all things. Our MC is literally named "Justice", and has the best super power that is activated for free by the nature of him being the biggest, most tired trope. We have childhood-friend-big-tits McGee who is overused for the short half of the series that she is alive for the purposes of otaku pandering fanservice shots and light novel powertrip fantasies. We have Rin Tohsaka look-alike Antagonist Hime, who is incredibly gay and not much else. Like, no, she's actually a lesbian and the occasional yuribait jokes (of which there are maybe 4 or 5 total) are the only thing that even got me to look up from my phone. There's also the best fucking character ever, Bluesy Fruesy, the American secret services agent that's been sent to Japan to oversee tattao collection. Bluesy. Fruesy. That is a characters fucking actual name.

This show is an absolute dumpster fire. It regularly set new lows for the entire medium every single fucking week. Avoid it like the plague. I sat through it so you don't have to. The worst about it is that MAL and AL won't let me rate it a 0 because the site doesn't support a rating that bad.

I'll probably get flamed for this because this show was just so popular, but I did not like this show at all, nor did I think it was even good. Like, I get it, the show was trying to be really "progressive" by having pretty much a legitimately gay couple, but I don't even think that was really that crazy, considering three other shows this season had pretty blatant lesbian couples or baiting (Izetta, Flip Flappers, Hibike). Yeah, that might not have go so far as to show a kiss in the middle of a crowded sports stadium, but being bold doesn't really make a show good unless you judge every show you watch on a scale of Tumblr-acceptance levels. The story in all honesty was pretty typical for that of a sports anime, as were all the characters. Yuri is our typical protagonist, Yurio is the angry rival, etc etc..., none of these characters are anything new or novel. 

I will admit that this show came out of the gate firing aesthetically. The first episode looked like a movie, but to say the show couldn't keep this up was an understatement. Skate animation was incredibly good to start, but the show did the most heinous thing that anime can do starting about halfway through, and that's REUSING FRAMES. From episode six or so to the end, the ONLY new piece of skate animation for any of Yuri's routines was the quad flip in his last routine, with every other piece of animation being reused. I can appreciate the difficulty of animating figure skating, but I can NEVER forgive such blatant reuse of frames. There are tons of different angles that could have been explored to keep animation fresh, but it honestly felt like I was watching the same episode over and over again throughout the entire second half of the show. The music did almost nothing to add to the hype, with Yuri's track in particular having an incredible build up and then no substance after the drop, disappointing you rather than making his eventual victories feel like, well, victories. One thing I will praise though is the VA, with Yuri in particular having personality in bounds that I wish I heard more in that kind of character. The modesty/skill disparity that Yuri's character archetype holds comes off as genuine only because of his VA, and not much else.

I get why this show was well received, but once the season passes and those touting the "progressive"-ness of it move on to the next thing, I think that it will be forgotten. In reality, it's just another Free!; a show that panders to a very niche market that just ended up luckily getting a good amount of exposure.

I've been baited by the damn semicolon. After coming off Occultic;Nine last season, I thought I could at the very least find some sort of intrigue to enjoy here. I knew that the prequel to this series, Chaos;Head, was near universally panned, but Silver Link had me interested when they offered up a special "recap" of Chaos;Head re-animated and clarified as episode one. After that (and a trip to the Chaos;Head wiki), I felt pretty confident that I'd be able to understand what was going to happen in Chaos;Child. I couldn't have been more wrong, and I'm 99.99% sure that it isn't even my fault. 

Now, although Child is definitely a sequel to Head, the new plot of Child more so builds off of the results of Head instead of continuing some sort of overarching narrative. The show sets itself up as some sort of supernatural murder mystery concerning psychic powers. Not a bad premise but certainly not something terribly original. Of course it's set in high school, and we've got probably the most stereotypical cast of visual novel characters of all time. I've already made it a habit of rattling off tropes so I'll spare you this time, but just know that there is nothing original or interesting about our characters here... at least not at first. As the incredibly convoluted and confusing story plods forward, a two or three of them start to become slightly more interesting with their own sorry excuses for motivations other than "let's solve the mystery because MC likes mysteries". 

As the plot all comes vomiting out after about the first five or six episodes of doing next to nothing to advance it, it becomes terribly apparent just how poorly the adaptation was done. Chaos;Child is a pretty well liked and in-depth visual novel with ~50+ hours of gameplay, so a branching narrative is obviously one of its strong points. In adapting that, the directors chose to basically "set up" everything first, which lead to the 5 or 6  episodes of no advancement and the subsequent vomit. I don't understand why anime directors think they can get away with these "condensed" VN adaptations. We need look no further than the original Fate/Stay Night by DEEN to realize that this approach is never going to work well. 

In Chaos;Child's case, this just makes the already pretty weak climax and "twist" we are presented with in the second half feel even more out-of-left-field and not genuine than they already would have if the director would have just stuck to adapting one VN route. This isn't even acknowledging the other ridiculous plot points, such as Nono being shanked in an alley and left for dead, surviving as if nothing had happened, and instead of being hospitalized just being laid down in her home, TREATED BY HER FRIENDS AS IF SHE HAD A COLD. The utter insanity of how some of these actions play out (and are flat-out glossed over by the characters) is frankly unforgivable.

Go read a synopsis, and if it sounds even remotely interesting to you, just go out and play the VN. There's honestly nothing to enjoy here in the adaptation outside of possibly the first episode and some incredibly generic art, character designs, and music.

This show is beyond terrible. I picked it up based on the ridiculous premise but instead of being a fun and moderately good time like Akiba'S Trip, it was an unfunny and tired slog for a total of 25 uninspired episodes. Every character can be boiled down to exactly one word. They have no motivations or personality outside of this word. The "classical musician" shtick is poorly executed and barely utilized. Music, despite being apparently the focus of the series, made me want to tear my ears out. Visuals are some sort of thick-lined bullshit that looks like trash both in motions and in stills. There also is no plot to mention, with each episode being some sort of ridiculous one-shot that leaves the characters exactly as the began. 

Burn this show to the ground and protest outside of Sunrise offices to make Code Geass S3 amazing as retribution for wasting everyone's time with this garbage.

There's always that one romantic comedy or drama that comes along every once and a while, taking itself so seriously that it approaches the point of absurdity. Fuuka is one of the latter, and dear merciful Christ is it absurd. Fuuka is a story about love, music, and fucking both of those things up so hard that they don't even look like the same things on the other end. All of your favorite characters from all of fiction are present, like, MAIN CHARACTER and BLUE-HAIRED HEROINE. In a surprising turn of events, they end up going to a concert or some shit together after meeting on the roof (original idea do not steal), where they walk around a statue looking for each (on opposite sides) for FIVE. WHOLE. MINUTES. Because of this life changing experience of statue searching, blue-haired Fuuka decides she loves MC, who's name I couldn't care to remember if you threatened my life, and that she OWNS him and MUST have his love. Of course instead of telling him this, she acts all pouty and sad for 12 episodes instead.

Fuuka leads everyone on by coming up with this stupid idea to start a band and play cover songs, to which everyone agrees is an amazing idea for no reason. Fuuka can sing because plot convenience, and MC decides that he'll learn to play bass because he's cursed with crippling beta-itis. They then gather your typical group of magically musically competant high-schoolers, such as SPORTS McDRUMMERGUY, RICHY PIANO-PANTS, and CEVANT GUITAR-GIRL. Guitar-Girl is seemingly a mute until she notices that she talks to MC on Twitter. This unbreakable bond that could stretch across universes and destroy galaxies cures her of her mute and stoic attitude, and this facet of her character is never explored again. Because of Twitter.

Everyone's rose-colored dreams of starting a band a destroyed by MC's celebrity childhood friend, SHIRAYUKI'S VA. She's hopelessly in love with MC and became a successful solo artist by only writing songs about she loves MC for no reason other than being the doomed-to-lose childhood friend trope. This creates all sorts of wacky situations for the band, like going to the beach and being mad for no reason, getting stoned to death on stage because of a misunderstanding, and generally having severe bouts of anime-romance induced autism. Oh, and at the end of it all Fuuka runs away from everything to become a solo artist because it's impossible for the heroine to be forward with her feelings despite being an incredibly forward personality in all other facets of their character so we'll have two more episodes I guess.

In an incredibly ballsy move, the show actually puts SHIRAYUKI'S VA and MC in a relationship, which is satisfying for all of 3 minutes until you realize that even SHIRAYUKI'S VA is just a hollow husk of nothingness that you've projected the motivations and charm of another character on for no reason other than that they had the same voice actress. MC then continues to sulk about how his beautiful celebrity girlfriend, reasonably successful band, and overall perfect highschool existence just isn't fucking good enough for him. He ends up dumping celebrity girlfriend because he realizes that he loves Fuuka because of plot convenience and no real character motivations other than that "it was episode 12 and we needed a climax".

I wrote this before the last episode aired and I don't give a flying fuck how it ended. Fuuka is everything wrong with anime romance drama rolled up and decorated with a nice little bow. They should show this shit to directors as an example of what to NEVER DO. The entire experience feels like if someone really not-talented watched White Album 2 and said "Hey man I can do that I think". Thankfully they had someone with real talent draw a couple of the character designs because even though they're generic as all fuck at least they are sort of pretty to look at as the rest of the plot burns down in a blazing fire of autism.

Leave this show in the dumpster fire it belongs in.

This show came out of the gate over-edgy and terrible, with lines like, "The pain is the only thing that makes me feel alive," but I knew it going in. In fact, it was recommended to me over Twitter as a meme show, but dear god did I not realize just how bad it would become. It was ALWAYS bad, with the first half's ED being the best part of the show by far, but it just slowly and slowly became more and more incomprehensible as the episodes ticked up towards 25. Events happen at random, characters act without motivation, conflict falls out of immaterial space. Here is an example of something that happens in the show:

"The main character attempts to grapple onto a stratospheric jet with his wristwatch by driving a scooter off a ramp into the air. When he fails to make enough distance, he activates his previously unseen ROCKET SHOES to fly up and complete the grapple."

This show is not meant to be funny. It's not a comedy, it's not a parody, and it's not some sort of 2deep4u "this is supposed to be bad" bullshit (Mayoiga). This scene is meant to be the HYPE CLIMAX for our MYSTERY SHOUNEN SERIES. I'm just done. Shows like this really fucking challenge my #NoDrop because unlike shows like Fuuka or Chaos;Child where they are terrible or bad, they at least have something for me to say about them in a review, but here there is just nothing. On top of a complete and utter lack of substance, the show also looks like complete garbage. The manga its adapted from looks like it was drawn by a blind fourth grader, and THAT looks better than the anime.

Little did I know that "The pain is the only thing that makes me feel alive," would perfectly describe the only way I could tell that I was still living when episode 25 ended.

This show is NOT about games, gamers, or anything relating to games. These things definitely exist in the show, but it's not about them in the slightest. You know what is the focus? A fucking misunderstanding and a love hexagon. I queued this show up because I saw one girl in the show's gaming club main Elphelt in Guilty Gear: Xrd Rev2, and I've been regretting it ever since. Absolutely pants-on-head retarded main character, completely unbelievable love interest, and a supporting cast so flat and uninteresting that I couldn't possibly tell you any of their names. To make matters worse, this show straight up looks like fucking garbage; character designs are as bland as they could possibly be and there's nothing to even be said about how things look in motion. The animation practically melts off the fucking screen into liquified garbage, and there isn't even any decent music to distract from the visuals sans the acceptable OP. 

If you want a romantic comedy about video games, go watch Netoge no Yoma wa Onnanoko ja Nai to Omotta instead. The fact that I have actually recommended something that trashy and with such a terribly long and ridiculous name should speak volumes to how terrible Gamers! really is.
